Adds Microsoft Graph environment to the settings file.
The environment name.

command:example.maml:title: ----------- Example 1: Add user defined environment -----------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Add-MgEnvironment -Name "Canary" -GraphEndpoint "https://canary.graph.microsoft.com" -AzureADEndpoint "https://login.microsoftonline.com" Name AzureADEndpoint GraphEndpoint Type ---- --------------- ------------- ---- Canary https://login.microsoftonline.com https://microsoftgraph.com User-defined

dev:remarks.maml:para: Adds user defined environment.

maml:description.maml:para: Microsoft Graph PowerShell supports two types of authentication: delegated and app-only access. There are a number of cmdlets that can be used to manage the different parameters required during authentication, for example, environment, application ID, and certificate.
You must invoke Connect-MgGraph before any commands that access Microsoft Graph. This cmdlet gets the access token using the Microsoft Authentication Library
Specifies a bearer token for Microsoft Graph service. Access tokens do timeout and you'll have to handle their refresh.
Sets the HTTP client timeout in seconds.
The name of the national cloud environment to connect to. By default global cloud is used.
Hides the welcome message.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
The client id of your application.
The subject distinguished name of a certificate. The Certificate will be retrieved from the current user's certificate store.
The thumbprint of your certificate. The Certificate will be retrieved from the current user's certificate store.
An X.509 certificate supplied during invocation.
Sets the HTTP client timeout in seconds.
Determines the scope of authentication context. This accepts `Process` for the current process, or `CurrentUser` for all sessions started by user.
The name of the national cloud environment to connect to. By default global cloud is used.
Hides the welcome message.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Include x5c header in client claims when acquiring a token to enable subject name / issuer based authentication using given certificate.

The id of the tenant to connect to. You can also use this parameter to specify your sign-in audience. i.e., common, organizations, or consumers. See https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/develop/msal-client-application-configuration#authority.
The client id of your application.
An array of delegated permissions to consent to.
Sets the HTTP client timeout in seconds.
Determines the scope of authentication context. This accepts `Process` for the current process, or `CurrentUser` for all sessions started by user.
The name of the national cloud environment to connect to. By default global cloud is used.
Hides the welcome message.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

The id of the tenant to connect to. You can also use this parameter to specify your sign-in audience. i.e., common, organizations, or consumers. See https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/develop/msal-client-application-configuration#authority.
Use device code authentication instead of a browser control.
The client id of your application.
Login using a Managed Identity.
Sets the HTTP client timeout in seconds.
Determines the scope of authentication context. This accepts `Process` for the current process, or `CurrentUser` for all sessions started by user.

The PSCredential object provides the application ID and client secret for service principal credentials. For more information about the PSCredential object, type Get-Help Get-Credential.
Sets the HTTP client timeout in seconds.
Determines the scope of authentication context. This accepts `Process` for the current process, or `CurrentUser` for all sessions started by user.
The name of the national cloud environment to connect to. By default global cloud is used.
Hides the welcome message.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

The id of the tenant to connect to. You can also use this parameter to specify your sign-in audience. i.e., common, organizations, or consumers. See https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/develop/msal-client-application-configuration#authority.
Sets the HTTP client timeout in seconds.
Determines the scope of authentication context. This accepts `Process` for the current process, or `CurrentUser` for all sessions started by user.
The name of the national cloud environment to connect to. By default global cloud is used.
Allows for authentication using environment variables configured on the host machine. See https://github.com/Azure/azure-sdk-for-net/tree/main/sdk/identity/Azure.Identity#environment-variables.
Hides the welcome message.

Specifies a bearer token for Microsoft Graph service. Access tokens do timeout and you'll have to handle their refresh.

The thumbprint of your certificate. The Certificate will be retrieved from the current user's certificate store.
The client id of your application.
The PSCredential object provides the application ID and client secret for service principal credentials. For more information about the PSCredential object, type Get-Help Get-Credential.
Sets the HTTP client timeout in seconds.
Determines the scope of authentication context. This accepts `Process` for the current process, or `CurrentUser` for all sessions started by user.
The name of the national cloud environment to connect to. By default global cloud is used.

The id of the tenant to connect to. You can also use this parameter to specify your sign-in audience. i.e., common, organizations, or consumers. See https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/azure/active-directory/develop/msal-client-application-configuration#authority.
Use device code authentication instead of a browser control.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Delegated access: Using interactive authentication, where you provide the scopes that you require during your session
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Connect-MgGraph -Scopes "User.Read.All", "Group.ReadWrite.All"

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows how to authenticate to graph with scopes.

command:example.maml:title: ----- Example 2: Delegated access: Using device code flow -----
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Connect-MgGraph -Scopes "User.Read.All", "Group.ReadWrite.All" -UseDeviceAuthentication

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows how to authenticate to graph with scopes and device.

command:example.maml:title: --- Example 3: Delegated access: Using your own access token ---
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Connect-MgGraph -AccessToken $AccessToken

dev:remarks.maml:para: This example shows how to authenticate to graph using an access token.

command:example.maml:title: Example 4: Delegated access: custom application for Microsoft Graph PowerShell
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Connect-MgGraph -ClientId <YOUR_NEW_APP_ID> -TenantId <YOUR_TENANT_ID>

dev:remarks.maml:para: Follow this link (https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/microsoftgraph/authentication-commands?view=graph-powershell-1.0#using-connect-mggraph)for more information on the steps for creating custom applications.

command:example.maml:title: Example 5: App-only access: Using client credential with a certificate - Certificate Thumbprint
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Connect-MgGraph -ClientId "YOUR_APP_ID" -TenantId "YOUR_TENANT_ID" -CertificateThumbprint "YOUR_CERT_THUMBPRINT"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Follow this link (https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/microsoftgraph/authentication-commands?view=graph-powershell-1.0#using-connect-mggraph)for more information on how to load the certificate.

command:example.maml:title: Example 6: App-only access: Using client credential with a certificate - Certificate name
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Connect-MgGraph -ClientId "YOUR_APP_ID" -TenantId "YOUR_TENANT_ID" -CertificateName "YOUR_CERT_SUBJECT"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Follow this link (https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/microsoftgraph/authentication-commands?view=graph-powershell-1.0#using-connect-mggraph)for more information on how to load the certificate.

command:example.maml:title: Example 7: App-only access: Using client credential with a certificate - Certificate
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $Cert = Get-ChildItem Cert:\LocalMachine\My\$CertThumbprint PS C:\> Connect-MgGraph -ClientId "YOUR_APP_ID" -TenantId "YOUR_TENANT_ID" -Certificate $Cert

dev:remarks.maml:para: Follow this link (https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/microsoftgraph/authentication-commands?view=graph-powershell-1.0#using-connect-mggraph)for more information on how to load the certificate.

command:example.maml:title: ---------- Example 8: Using client secret credentials ----------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> $ClientSecretCredential = Get-Credential -Credential "Client_Id" # Enter client_secret in the password prompt. PS C:\> Connect-MgGraph -TenantId "Tenant_Id" -ClientSecretCredential $ClientSecretCredential

dev:remarks.maml:para: This authentication method is ideal for background interactions. It does not require a user to physically sign in.

command:example.maml:title: Example 9: Using managed identity: System-assigned managed identity
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Connect-MgGraph -Identity

dev:remarks.maml:para: Uses an automatically managed identity on a service instance. The identity is tied to the lifecycle of a service instance.

command:example.maml:title: Example 10: Using managed identity: User-assigned managed identity
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Connect-MgGraph -Identity -ClientId "User_Assigned_Managed_identity_Client_Id"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Uses a user created managed identity as a standalone Azure resource.

command:example.maml:title: ------ Example 11: Connecting to an environment or cloud ------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-MgEnvironment Name AzureADEndpoint GraphEndpoint Type ---- --------------- ------------- ---- China https://login.chinacloudapi.cn https://microsoftgraph.chinacloudapi.cn Built-in Global https://login.microsoftonline.com https://graph.microsoft.com Built-in USGov https://login.microsoftonline.us https://graph.microsoft.us Built-in USGovDoD https://login.microsoftonline.us https://dod-graph.microsoft.us Built-in PS C:\> Connect-MgGraph -Environment USGov

dev:remarks.maml:para: When you use Connect-MgGraph, you can choose to target other environments. By default, Connect-MgGraph targets the global public cloud.

command:example.maml:title: Example 12: Connecting to an environment as a different identity
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Connect-MgGraph -ContextScope Process

dev:remarks.maml:para: To connect as a different identity other than CurrentUser, specify the -ContextScope parameter with the value Process.

maml:description.maml:para: Once you're signed in, you'll remain signed in until you invoke Disconnect-MgGraph. Microsoft Graph PowerShell automatically refreshes the access token for you and sign-in persists across PowerShell sessions because Microsoft Graph PowerShell securely caches the token.
Use Disconnect-MgGraph to sign out.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

command:example.maml:title: ------------- Example 1: Using Disconnect-MgGraph -------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Disconnect-MgGraph

dev:remarks.maml:para: Use Disconnect-MgGraph to sign out.

maml:description.maml:para: Get-MgContext is used to retrieve the details about your current session, which include: - ClientID - TenantID - Certificate Thumbprint - Scopes consented to - AuthType: Delegated or app-only - AuthProviderType - CertificateName - Account - AppName - ContextScope - Certificate - PSHostVersion - ClientTimeOut.
Retrieves session details.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

command:example.maml:title: ---------------- Example 1: Using Get-MgContext ----------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-MgContext ClientId : 615e6e7c-aa11-4402-91a1-6234967405d5 TenantId : 9f32a42e-6782-4b96-a4d3-e0828a292569 CertificateThumbprint : Scopes : {AppRoleAssignment.ReadWrite.All, Directory.AccessAsUser.All, Directory.ReadWrite.All, EntitlementManagement.ReadWrite.All...} AuthType : Delegated AuthProviderType : InteractiveAuthenticationProvider CertificateName : Account : admin@Contoso.com AppName : Microsoft Graph PowerShell ContextScope : CurrentUser Certificate : PSHostVersion : 5.1.17763.1 ClientTimeout : 00:05:00

dev:remarks.maml:para: Retrieves session details.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Using Get-MgContext: Retrieve all scopes you've consented to
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-MgContext | Select -ExpandProperty Scopes AppRoleAssignment.ReadWrite.All Directory.AccessAsUser.All Directory.ReadWrite.All EntitlementManagement.ReadWrite.All Group.ReadWrite.All openid Organization.Read.All profile RoleManagement.ReadWrite.Directory User.Read User.ReadWrite.All

dev:remarks.maml:para: Retrieves all scopes.

maml:description.maml:para: When you use Connect-MgGraph, you can choose to target other environments. By default, Connect-MgGraph targets the global public cloud.
When you use Connect-MgGraph, you can choose to target other environments. By default, Connect-MgGraph targets the global public cloud.
The environment name.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
The environment name.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

command:example.maml:title: ----------------- Example 1: Get-MgEnvironment -----------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-MgEnvironment Name AzureADEndpoint GraphEndpoint Type ---- --------------- ------------- ---- China https://login.chinacloudapi.cn https://microsoftgraph.chinacloudapi.cn Built-in Global https://login.microsoftonline.com https://graph.microsoft.com Built-in USGov https://login.microsoftonline.us https://graph.microsoft.us Built-in USGovDoD https://login.microsoftonline.us https://dod-graph.microsoft.us Built-in

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets list of all environments.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets global configurations that apply to the SDK. For example, check if Web Account Manager (WAM) support has been enabled.
Gets global configurations that apply to the SDK. For example, check if Web Account Manager (WAM) support has been enabled.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

command:example.maml:title: ------- Example 1: Check if WAM support has been enabled -------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-MgGraphOption EnableWAMForMSGraph -------------------- True

dev:remarks.maml:para: Confirms if WAM support has been enabled.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets graph request context details
Gets graph request context details
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: ---------------- Example 1: Get request context ----------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Get-MgRequestContext ClientTimeout RetryDelay MaxRetry RetriesTimeLimit ------------- ---------- -------- ---------------- 00:00:05 3 2 00:00:02

dev:remarks.maml:para: Gets graph request context details

maml:description.maml:para: Invoke-MgGraphRequest issues REST API requests to the Graph API. It works for any Graph API if you know the REST URI, method, and optional body parameter. This command is especially useful for accessing APIs for which there isn't an equivalent cmdlet yet.
This command issues REST API requests.
HTTP Method
Add headers to Request Header collection without validation
Custom Content Type
Specifies a web request session. Enter the variable name, including the dollar sign ($).You can't use the SessionVariable and GraphRequestSession parameters in the same command.
Response Headers Variable
Response Status Code Variable
Skip Checking HTTP Errors
Custom Graph Request Session
Custom User Specified User Agent
Output Type to return to the caller
Uri to call can be segments such as /beta/me or fully qualified https://graph.microsoft.com/beta/me
Request Body. Required when Method is Post or Patch
Optional Custom Headers
Output file where the response body will be saved
Infer output filename
Input file to send in the request
Indicates that the cmdlet returns the results, in addition to writing them to a file. Only valid when the OutFile parameter is also used.

Request Body. Required when Method is Post or Patch
Custom Content Type
Custom Graph Request Session
Optional Custom Headers

Output file where the response body will be saved
Output Type to return to the caller
Indicates that the cmdlet returns the results, in addition to writing them to a file. Only valid when the OutFile parameter is also used.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Response Headers Variable
Specifies a web request session. Enter the variable name, including the dollar sign ($).You can't use the SessionVariable and GraphRequestSession parameters in the same command.

Custom User Specified User Agent

command:example.maml:title: ------------ Example 1: Using Invoke-MgGraphRequest ------------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Invoke-MgGraphRequest -Method GET https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/me Name Value ---- ----- userPrincipalName admin@Contoso.com preferredLanguage en-US mobilePhone 425-555-0101 displayName MOD Administrator givenName MOD mail admin@contoso.com @odata.context https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0/$metadata#users/$entity id 694bab60-392a-4f64-9430-c1dea2951f50 jobTitle officeLocation businessPhones {425-555-0100} surname Administrator

dev:remarks.maml:para: Issues REST API requests.

command:example.maml:title: ------ Example 1: Set environment for the current session ------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-MgEnvironment -GraphEndpoint "https://canary.graph.microsoft.com" -AzureADEndpoint "https://login.microsoftonline.com"

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sets the environment for the current session.

maml:description.maml:para: Sets global configurations that apply to the SDK. For example, toggle Web Account Manager (WAM) support.
Sets global configurations that apply to the SDK. For example, toggle Web Account Manager (WAM) support.
{{ Fill EnableLoginByWAM Description }}
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
{{ Fill EnableLoginByWAM Description }}
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}

command:example.maml:title: ---------- Example 1: Set web account manager support ----------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-MgGraphOption -EnableLoginByWAM $True

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sets web account manager support

maml:description.maml:para: Sets request context for Microsoft Graph invocations
Sets request context for Microsoft Graph invocations
Sets the HTTP client timeout in seconds.
Sets the maximum number of retries for a request with a maximum value of 10. This defaults to 3.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Sets the maximum time in seconds allowed for request retries.
Sets the waiting time in seconds before retrying a request with a maximum value of 180 seconds. This defaults to 3 seconds.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.
Sets the HTTP client timeout in seconds.
Sets the maximum number of retries for a request with a maximum value of 10. This defaults to 3.
{{ Fill ProgressAction Description }}
Sets the maximum time in seconds allowed for request retries.
Sets the waiting time in seconds before retrying a request with a maximum value of 180 seconds. This defaults to 3 seconds.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: -------- Example 1: Set Http client timeout in seconds --------
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-MgRequestContext -ClientTimeout 5 ClientTimeout RetryDelay MaxRetry RetriesTimeLimit ------------- ---------- -------- ---------------- 00:00:05 3 2 00:00:00

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sets Http client timeout in seconds.

command:example.maml:title: Example 2: Set the maximum time in seconds allowed for request retries
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-MgRequestContext -RetriesTimeLimit 2 ClientTimeout RetryDelay MaxRetry RetriesTimeLimit ------------- ---------- -------- ---------------- 00:00:05 3 2 00:00:02

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sets the maximum time in seconds allowed for request retries.

command:example.maml:title: -- Example 3: Set the maximum number of retries for a request --
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-MgRequestContext -MaxRetry 2 ClientTimeout RetryDelay MaxRetry RetriesTimeLimit ------------- ---------- -------- ---------------- 00:00:05 3 2 00:00:02

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sets the maximum number of retries for a request.

command:example.maml:title: Example 4: Set the waiting time in seconds before retrying a request
command:example.dev:code: PS C:\> Set-MgRequestContext -RetryDelay 3 ClientTimeout RetryDelay MaxRetry RetriesTimeLimit ------------- ---------- -------- ---------------- 00:00:05 3 2 00:00:02

dev:remarks.maml:para: Sets the waiting time in seconds before retrying a request.
